ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: none
1-2 hours
None

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Loved the seminar, great speakers. I do however, wish there were alternatives to pizza every week.
The speakers were pretty good this semester.
A better location. Bring speakers from industry and organizations such as the CDC, NIH, and FDA. Should have professors choose speakers or colleagues from other institutions.

I really enjoyed the talks but would prefer to hear a little more from a wider range of public health professionals. Also, it would be nice to not sit through the same talks we had in our Principles of Infectious Disease course- we heard from the same person three times on the same topic. Otherwise, I really enjoyed these lectures and look forward to attend some next semester.
Some lectures were really interesting and seemed relevant. Some were painfully boring to sit through and didn't make sense at all for EMD students.

Enjoyed very much Dr. Mike Begon and Dr. Les Real. Would like to seem more modeling and zoonotic disease (as a personal preference). Liked that the class met every week and covered variety of subjects.Side note: Although pizza is delicious and I am happy the seminar has food, having sandwiches every-so-often might be nice.
Great set of seminars from public health professionals from multiple fields and schools.
Not well structured for MPH students. Lack of resources in classes v2 makes it very inconvenient. Starting with having syllabus and resources in classes v2 would help a lot

Strengths: There were many wonderful speakers this semester who presented on a wide variety of topics, which is very useful to first-year students who are exploring various research areas. Weaknesses: I would have liked to have seen more individuals engaged in public health practice, as opposed to research.
The seminars and speakers were all great
Great way to be introduced to research in EMD and associated departments/faculty outside of EMD. Would be great to have something other than pizza sometimes.
Mandatory

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Albert Ko  Good. Asks questions to generate conversation.
Instructor: Albert Ko  n/a
Instructor: Albert Ko  Dr. Ko was great

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Required
I would recommend this seminar. There are plenty of extremely interesting talks, especially involving work that is done here at Yale. I look forward to next year's seminars as well. Thank you!
not bad, sometimes even fascinating
Would recommend as way to stay current on EMD research topics.
I would recommend it because it is required but it is also useful for a student who is looking for a particular public health interest and needs a push in a certain direction or another.
Great class to learn about research at YSPH but needs improvement
I would recommend this course to another student. This is a great opportunity to hear from and to ask questions of individuals from all over the field of public health!
Yes I would recommend this seminar to other students
